module.name: derived_shape_element
module.purpose:
This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of shape elements that are derived from other shape elements. It provides a general means for identifying sets of points as being derived from elements of a the shape of a part.
The designation of a shape element as "derived" means that it is determined from other shape elements, according to some process. This part of ISO 10303 is intended to support the processes of Geometric dimensioning and tolerancing in a design context, and also be usable in other application contexts such as manufacturing planning and dimensional inspection. This part of ISO 10303 does not specify the process by which the derivation is performed.
The concepts standardized herein may have general applicability , and this part of 10303 does not limit their use to geometric dimensioning and tolerancing.
Derived shape elements are derived from a physical (imperfect) workpiece or from a design. They may be themselves form part of the surface of the part, or may be inside or outside the part.
The centre of a hole is outside the part. The centre of a bolt is inside the partA mathematically defined cylinder that is fit to the surface of a hole is a shape element that is derived from the imperfect feature of a workpiece.
A mathematical straight line is derived from the imperfect median curve. The curve is the set of centres of circles which are fit to the actual hole at a particular depths. Each is shape element is derived from the precending shape element

inscope.li: specification of elements of a product shape as being derived from other elements of shape.

aa.refpath: derived_shape_aspect <= shape_aspect shape_aspect <- shape_aspect_relationship.relating_shape_aspect shape_aspect_relationship {shape_aspect_relationship => shape_aspect_deriving_relationship} shape_aspect_relationship.related_shape_aspect -> shape_aspect

derived_shape_aspect <= shape_aspect shape_aspect shape_definition = shape_aspect shape_definition characterized_definition = shape_definition characterized_definition <- property_definition.definition property_definition represented_definition = property_definition represented_definition <- property_definition_representation.definition property_definition_representation property_definition_representation.used_representation -> representation representation.items[i] -> representation_item representation_item => geometric_representation_item
